posts.name: Nathan Zhou
posts.cooked: Yes. As long as you donâ€™t initialize the tag you are using using the app. Cycle count only increments when charger log is added. See screenshot of the Android app.

posts.name: Nathan Zhou
posts.cooked: Total discharge energy will not be recorded. However, this can be obtained by pulling log from Android app and doing some data analysis. Assume no log is lost.

posts.name: Nathan Zhou
posts.cooked: A progress update: The RoboRIO driver is mostly completed. RoboRIO now can read battery information and send data to Arduino. [Image source] Documentation indicates that FRC's CAN spec mentions time and date in heartbeat data, but decoding reveals it's a time countdown. Therefore, the goal is to have RoboRIO send datetime, voltage, and energy to ESP32. Here's the plan: 1. ESP32 scans for readers upon startup, locks onto one, collects battery data, and sends it to CAN. 2. Once connected to the Driver Station, records are created with initial zeros. 3. Upon receiving a meaningful timestamp, updates the record. 4. Monitors voltage during operation and records the lowest value. 5. Disabling the robot writes the current timestamp, voltage, and energy to the battery. 6. Re-enabling triggers another record update. 7. After discharging, data is accessible via an Android app.

posts.name: Nathan Zhou
posts.cooked: The reader logic is nearly complete, although a minor issue still exists. The project involves developing a Battery Tracking system for FRC-Custom-CAN-Sensor, and contributions can be made to sikaxn/FRC-Custom-CAN-Sensor on GitHub. Additionally, a CSV file exported from an Android app appears below, though it currently contains some inconsistencies. Two image screenshots are available at the following URLs: one at c130279e9292de87dfd12a476bc3ddae9d8f36ea.png and another at d63209dc8b114a74643468e0af2d20e46655d86e.png.

posts.name: Nathan Zhou
posts.cooked: The text is about automating the discovery and monitoring of power distribution devices on a CAN bus, specifically addressing the challenges of energy calculation due to the absence of built-in features in REV PDH devices compared to CTRE PDP 1.0. The author acknowledges difficulties in handling asynchronous CAN communication, managing voltage and current data integration, and dealing with potential communication failures or device malfunctions. The solution requires careful consideration of sampling rates, synchronization of data streams, effective error handling, and reliable data processing without active command transmission capabilities.

link_counts.title: FRC-Custom-CAN-Sensor/scripts/PDautoDiscoveryReadData.py at main Â· sikaxn/FRC-Custom-CAN-Sensor Â· GitHub

posts.name: Nathan Zhou
posts.cooked:
This will be the last update to battery tracking unless a significant bug is found until next season.

Power distribution device (CTRE PDP 1.0 or REV PDH) on CAN bus will be automatically discovered. This means no code is needed on roboRIO if you don't need to read battery data. However, your PD must be connected to CAN. If PD cannot connect to CAN or CTRE PDP 2.0 is used, roboRIO code is required to write the lowest voltage to the battery and energy won't be accounted.

This version calculates total energy using voltage and current in 100ms sample rate via a dedicated task. My implementation is still rough.

Date/time is pulled from roboRIO heartbeat via @Thad_House on CAN message bits. All dates are saved in UTC in RFID tags and displayed locally on the Android app.

If anyone has suggestions or finds bugs, please reply here. It's been a lot of learning!
